Description: Fragmentary portrait of a woman in tempera on wood, inscribed in Greek 'Serapi[as]': only the left edge of the panel is preserved with sand and mastic on the back. Visible are the proper right ear, the lower lid and part of the pupil of the right eye, the nose from bridge to nostril and part of both cheeks. In her pierced ear the woman wears a gold hoop earring threaded with pearls, of which two are visible. Above them two corkscrew locks of black hair hang in front of the ear. The flesh is warmly tinted in tones of cream, apricot and rose pink with an ochre-green shadow by the nose. The nostrils are drawn in dark red.
Curator's comments: The corkscrew locks indicate a date in the very early years of the second century AD, also appropriate for the hoop earrings. The name Sarapi(as), unknown in other mummy portraits, is well attested, for example in six papyri naming members of the 6,475 descendants of the Greek settlers in the Fayum. Bibliography: R. P.Hinks, 'A Catalogue of the Greek, Etruscan and Roman Paintings in the British Museum' (1933), 58 no. 86 fig. 65; K. Parlasca, Mumienporträts und verwandte Denkmäler (1966), 30 n. 93, 81 no. 13; B. Borg, ‘Mumienporträts. Chronologie und kulterelle Kontext (1996), 152m, 210 cat. 6; K. Parlasca & H. Seeman, ‘Augenblicke, Mumienporträts un ägyptische Grabkunst aus römischer Zeit’ (1999), 220 no. 127; S. Walker, 'Ancient Faces', New York 2000, p. 97 [58]. Parlasca, Mumienportrdts 30 n. 93, 81 no. 13; Borg 1996, 152m, 210 cat. 6; Parlasca and Seeman 1999, 220 no. 127.
Bibliographic references: Painting / Catalogue of the Greek, Etruscan & Roman Paintings & Mosaics in the British Museum: Paintings (86)
Walker, S 2000 / Ancient Faces: Mummy Portraits from Roman Egypt (58)
